title: What will be the closing stock price of Facebook on 5 August 2020?
preds: Given the current price of FB and one day volatility, we get the probability of staying in 230-260 bracket close to 99%
Adjusting for time decay. The forecast settles in one day.

If we use implied vol = 31.30 points, and the closing price on Aug 5, 2020 of $249.83, we get the 98-2 distribution.  Reasons for adjusts:
- There are no events tomorrow, so we do not expect any idiosyncratic vol. 
- However, stocks generally have fatter tails.  I do not adjust from the base rate.

Given the current amount of time remaining until expiration, price is almost guaranteed to fall in the middle bucket, with possible tail events causing a move to between $260 and $290 but negligible probability mass falling in the other buckets.

I am maintaining this as I think the market is efficient and already has absorbed the variance and news of earning and swings of 5 percent or more are a little hard to come by in very large cap stocks (value is basically set and less likely to move on no news and no macro news)

Update 8/4/2020: Given there's 1 day left to prediction expiry and stock is at 249.55, seems likely that it will end up in the 230-260 bucket. Options for Aug 7th are pricing $7.24 move so I have more than 1 straddle of margin on each side. Very comfortable with the middle 230-260 bucket.
Update based on current stock price
Stock is 248.72 and trending downward toward 245, a 5% move given no news is highly unlikely.

I'm updating my forecast to use updated options prices from the day before August 5. As before, I'm using the August 7 options. These options should overprice the strikes farther from the spread (with more time, the probability those strikes occur increases). Even with this overestimate of the ranges other than $230-260, the estimate still allocates most of the likelihood to the $230-260 range, so I felt like it was ok to not adjust from the August 7th options. However, given that the call option calculation I've been using is just to provide a good estimate, I've shifted the tails up slightly to account for errors in the model. As before, the 0% values are just rounded from numbers below 0.5%.

Facebook just opened at 251.60. I’ll update further after the full market open; however, it seems more unlikely Facebook will rip up given no clear events in sight that may cause that sudden ticker hike.

I took the straddle price that expires this Friday for FB (August 7th expiry) and back out the implied move, converted it to a percentage, converted this to a daily implied move, and then scaled to two days since that is when we will examine the close. The biggest change in my forecast here is incorporating the the new FB price after they beat earnings and the stock market reacted extremely positively and incorporating the new information implied by option prices. So, I found out that the one standard deviation move was $5.74, and then for rough approximation calculated CDF probabilities of a normal distribution with mean of the most recent close price (251.96) and standard deviation of $5.74

Updating as Facebook stock settled slightly down today, and theta is extremely high on this market as expiry approaches - a constriction and slight shift of distribution to the left gives the above probabilities.
Right in the middle of this tranche.
Unlikely to increase or decrease outside of this range after remaining largely constant for the past month.
Essentially two trading days left, so I am reducing the 3% risk I had for 200-230

Updating to reflect passage of time.  Same methodology as before, with slight adjustments to reflect expiration being slightly later than this question's end date.  Probability of <$200 is set as 0 because of rounding errors (actual should be a bit under half a percent).

With three days before the forecast expires, the price of Facebook’s stock is approximately 251. Given the time until settlement and the fact that the highest volatility event, earnings, has passed, I have a higher conviction that the price will not change significantly. As a result, probability mass is shifted to the current bucket.

FB closing price on Jul 31 is $253.67. There is little anticipated major news remaining. Thus, we get a base rate from assuming GBM stock moves, and 3 more variance days. The Aug 21 ATM calls imply an IVM of about 32. Scaling to three variance days, this implies a 23% chance to move greater than $260.00, a.3% chance of moving below $230. 
- The twelve month analyst estimates (https://money.cnn.com/quote/forecast/forecast.html?symb=FB#:~:text=Facebook%20Inc%20(NASDAQ%3AFB)&text=The%2042%20analysts%20offering%2012,the%20last%20price%20of%20253.87.) are biased upward, so I adjust 23% to 28%. 
- The GBM model implies a .3% chance of decreasing below $230. This would imply a decrease of 10% in 3 days. This is not unreasonable, Facebook's stock did this multiple times in March. Also, there is a tendency of the market to overreact to fundamental news. The price was only $234.50 on the close the day before. Thus we increase this value from the theoretical base rate to 2%.

8/3/20: Continuing to narrow range as days to expiry decreases. Currently 70% weighting in middle (230-260) bucket. Aug 7th straddle at $255 implies a 3.4% move. If an up move, will breach 260. Given that will take ~2% move up to breach and hold 260 level, more weight to middle bucket. Note that this is for options expiring on Aug 7th and this question asks about Aug 5th, so overall prob of moving is further decreased (ie greater percentage in middle bucket). Overall 70% in 230-260, 30% in 260-290.
Updating using S=253.3 and IVM = 30%, a massive drop post evenings as expected.

Updating forecast - constricting distribution slightly as time decays and the price hovers around $250-260. Also shifting probability density from 3rd to 4th bucket as the price moved slightly upwards towards $260. Calculations were done similarly to the first and second forecast.
It closed 253.67 Friday.  Only 3 days of trading left.  I don't know the scoring impact.

The actual price is about 250 following earnings growth release. Taking this into consideration and the increased valuation of technological stocks during the pandemic, it would not be surprising for Facebook share price to reach beyond 260 in a few days. 290 may be too early, especially considering that Apple may target Facebook advertising with ios 14.
Stocks are climbing with currently at around $253

Facebook had strong revenue in its 2020 Q2 earnings report leading to an increase in the ticker price to its current point at ~254. I believe it's safe to assume the majority of price discovery was taking into account on the 31st as remaining excess volatility rapidly diminishes in t+2 onwards after earnings historically. With all major predictable events out of way, There is some degree of likelihood that the stock generally drifts upward the remaining ~$6; thus we allocate a decent probability towards the 260-290 bucket.

With the major earnings release out of the way and FB currently trading at $253.67 as of the August 1 weekend, it seems safe to say that the price will most likely remain within the current bucket as there are no more serious stock-moving events priced in (and with most of the weekend gone, room for news release). There is some potential for the stock to move up into the higher bracket, though, with only $6.33 left until the next bucket lower range.

Facebook posted strong revenue for second qtr of 2020 and is now trading at 254. I will be assuming that most of price discovery has happened during the 31st and that we will not see as strong a move in the coming days. We might expect to see some positive drift, around 0.1% per day as estimated by the average drift of the last 2 months. So, I will shift my estimation distribution up.
Updating based on current price and perceived stability on last day of trading.

FB earnings exceeded analyst expectations on July 30, so stock was up 8.17% (+19.17) on Friday to 253.67 at the close. While there may be some momentum in the stock after earnings, there are only 3 trading days left before August 5. Stock needs to rise another 2.5% from its closing price to go over $260. Stock held pretty steady around $230-235 the week before earnings and was mostly fluctuating between $220 and $240 since late May. As a result, I think it is possible for the stock to fluctuate above $260 this coming week, but the probability that the closing price on August 5 is over $260 is lower. Therefore, FB is most likely to close in the $230-260 range, but surpassing $260 is also possible.
Nothing but government regs are going to slow this behemoth down.

The stock closed on 7/31 at 253.67, leaving three trading days left and needing to drop more than 10% to fall in the $200-$230 bucket, which has lead me to decrease my probability from 8% to 3%. The world is pricing it around 2% based on option prices. I think that the 5% should be split between the two categories because a 3% move is very possible if the market is up Monday & Tuesday

I guess markets will have a losing week before resolution of this question with abundant reasons, the latest of which is tropical storm "Isaias", which could strengthen again and organize into a hurricane, and now threatens to affect the entire East coast of the USA.
Although the facebook stock has de-coupled from Nasdaq 100 and has thus become an alpha trade over the last few days, earnings and news tend to be traded on only as long as they are rumors, and tend to stop doing so when they're facts.
I struggle to interpret the news on tiktok with regards to facebook's future, but when you look at it closely, the risk of espionage on personal data (especially when they get lost by the company) is not so much different from the one in facebook's data pile, so recommendations of the pentagon may also apply to facebook and their lax data handling. Combining this with the repeated congressional hearings, it seems to me that "nationalizing the data stock" could to be a target of national security authorities in the US with the "National Security interest" as a reason, in which a significantly lower prize and finally a buy-out could be the result. facebook already acts like a governmental body in times (e.g. supporting "predicitve policing"), so why not be a national agency openly in the future? To me it seems, the process has already started in 2020.  When I'm wrong on this, I'm going to be completely wrong...

Current price: 253,67
Bucket borders in percent: 79|91|102|114
Base rates over three business days: 0|2|70|27|1 crowd: 0|4|77|19|0
Corrected forecast: 0|3|71|25|1
Updating my forecast using the same methodology as my past forecast. Most of the change is driven the earnings report event which is a surprise to the market.

Current FB price is 253.67 by the close of July 31st. We shifted our base case to the range of 230 - 260. Given Trump is considering a direct ban on TikTok instead of selling to Microsoft, this is positive to FB's stock price. So, I updated my forecast as 3,10,45,38,4.
Adding more probability as Facebook’s earning beats market expectation.
Assuming normal distribution centered at latest stock price
I am adding more probability mass to the center and right of the distribution to reflect changes in stock price this morning after earnings.

After FB earnings, stock jumped from 230 to 250 on July 31. This increases the chance of a finish inside the 230-260 range. There is also a possibility of short-term momentum pulling the stock above 260 by August 5. Downside risk still remains due to hearings and investigation by the DOJ into big tech.

Forgot to take into account the company earnings report coming out, but luckily the implied volatility approach likely already priced that in. Facebook is currently at $252.05 as of 7/31/2020 10:46am EST, with ATM implied volatility at around 32.27% for Aug21, 2020 expiry. There should not be any major swings left, so going purely off the implied volatility, the market is predicting 0.0000/0.0160/0.7644/0.2195/0.0001. I believe this to be the best prediction.

I looked at the difference in options prices, which are now updated due to yesterday's earnings. I'm using the same method as before, so I won't show my work as in depth, but here are the options prices I've collected from July 31: Aug7 $200 put: $0.04
Aug7 $230 put: $0.42
Aug7 $260 call: $2.03
Aug7 $290 call: $0.14
Aug7 $260 put: $9.55
Aug7 $230 call: $23.00 This gives probabilities of: Less than 200: 0.23%
Between 200, 230: 2.2%
Between 230, 260: 86%
Between 260, 290: 10.8%
Above 290: 0.8% Rounding these gives me estimates of:
Less than 200: 0%
Between 200, 230: 2%
Between 230, 260: 86%
Between 260, 290: 11%
Above 290: 1% These numbers seem fairly reasonable.  I could make the tails a bit wider, but given that these options prices are for an exp date of August 7 instead of August 5 (when the question expires), these options prices slightly widen the tails naturally. There is much less volatility in stocks after earnings, and there are only 3 more market days before August 5. Any possible large movement would likely be triggered by a downturn, and the stock currently has $20 of leeway in the $230-$260 range on the down end (i.e. even if FB stock dropped $15, it would still lie between $230 and $260). This at least gives me some assurance in being 86% confident in the $230-$260 range, and to have little probability assigned to large moves.
Surpassing even my initial hunch: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1084233

Facebook is at 251 on the pre market earnings, and after today, there is no large volatility events in the next 3 days. As mentioned before, news in corona virus has not really impacted Facebook, unless it was a market wide decline. Even in the worst days, given the desensitized nature of the business world to new covid, I do not anticipate fb to drop 7% a day over the next few days (or drop 10% twice, and flat once), thus setting that probability to 0. Furthermore, a 18.5% increase on top of 7% on earnings is also going to occur less than 0.5%, so i set that probability to 0. Finally, the biggest shift is now that 200-230 is no longer highly likely, but instead possible but nor probable if earnings impact fade throughout the day or we see a fall on Monday.  I would like to shift 20 of that 28% between 56 and 12. I will update again at close today if stock deviates from 251.

Update 7/31/2020: narrowing range given FB's blowout quarter, removing weight from <200 and 200-230 buckets and shifting it to 260-290 bucket and taking 290+ weight and shifting to 230-260. Given that the question is expiring Aug 5th,  I believe there will be a relativity tight range for this answer and I will continue to narrow as we approach question expiry.

Updating due to volatility on FB earnings today - earnings were quite strong, beating expectating and seeing about a $15 increase in stock price. Given this high volatility event is over, and the stock price sits at about $250 after hours, I estimate a remaining volatility of about 0.45/sqrt(252)*sqrt(3) ~= 5% (based on ~45% implied vol, 252 trading days in a year, 3 trading days until Aug. 5 close). Then, a $10+ move to above $260 has about a 21% chance of happening, and a -$20+ move to below $230 has about a 5% chance of happening, under a normal distribution with standard deviation 5%. I fattened the tails somewhat to account for mis-estimation (similar effect of t-distribution), as well as the non-normality of stock returns.

I am adjusting my predictions to account for the passage of time and recent news. As the price is currently 234.50, I am removing probability mass from the tails as a large move is less likely given there is less time until expiry. Furthermore, Facebook beat expectations for its earnings and did not fall during the anti-trust congressional hearing. This makes a downwards move prior to Aug. 5 less likely.  However, given that Facebook’s price is close to 230 than 260, probability mass still must be maintained in the lower bucket.
Ok, Ok, so they had good numbers and the Robinhood crowd went nuts.
After announcing good quarterly results, FB is way up in after hours trading.  Keeping the most likely outcome at $230-260, but flipping the backup scenario from the low side to the high side.

I am updating my forecast in the wake of Facebook earnings being phenomenal. Right after their earnings we see a meteoric rise after hours, but should still be cautious of volatility in the after market.

I'll update this soon once our Bloomberg feeds update with new options prices, but FB stock just rose to about $245 from its earnings release. This is a quick estimate to update accordingly; a more detailed one is coming soon.
Updated post super positive earnings news

Analyzing 4-day returns over the period from the start of 2020 and assuming that the distribution of the returns will be the same over the next 4 days will be the same we get these probabilities. We can get another POV by assuming the stock price follows the GBM and try to obtain the distribution that way - this, however, results in probabilities very condensed around the current stock price even for large values of implied volatility (in comparison to the ones from the options data).

The fb stock traded up today with the market, the strenght of which is really surprising. However, the congressional hearings saw outraged members today on the one side, CEOs Zuck, Tim Apple[sic!], Bezos and Pichai calm but helplessly confronted with a wave of well-prepaired, grave allegations concerning different areas of charges on the other, not being able to make a single point.
Raising provisions to the likes of 5bn+ USD for settlement with the US justice (which is a typical way of getting rid of being held accountable for corporate giants; the Feds are in need of the money just now, nice coincidence) will be a wise decision for fb CFO D. Wehner - he's supposed to know how and why. And he will likely start with the quarterly report tomorrow, imho. There's much room for negative surprises, which is why I don't weigh more on the 230-260 bin so far.
Expecting the stock to fall after the Q2 earnings annoucement

With all the negative publicity, FB stock is likely going to take a hit, though not a huge one. Since its been bouncing between 230 and 250, its likely it will drop down closer to 215-220 by August 5th.
Decrease in days, but uptick in front week vol, roughly same prediction.

The current stock price is $234.63, so it seems like it will most likely fall between $200 and $260. It has recently been declining, but not by enough to fall below $200. It seems to fluctuate often, but I think the current trend (1 week away) will prevail.

Analyzing 5-day returns over the period from the start of 2020 and assuming that the distribution of the returns will be the same over the next 5 days will be the same we get these probabilities. We can get another POV by assuming the stock price follows the GBM and try to obtain the distribution that way - this, however, results in probabilities very condensed around the current stock price even for large values of implied volatility (in comparison to the ones from the options data).

Updating my prior due to the change in time. Again, Facebook is a relatively liquid stock and so the market pricing tends to be relatively efficient, and thus it makes sense to use call delta pricing. I did however slightly increase the tail ends of the probability since there are several tech earnings reports coming up.

The current price of FB is 233 on July 28. In a week's time following the House Antitrust testimony most likely Facebook will experience a few percentage point loss based on the negative press surrounding the breaches of trust and privacy to be discussed in the House. In 2019 after a similar hearing FB dropped about 2%, so a similar drop would put them barely below 230.

Currently, Facebook is priced at around $233. Facebook will be announcing earnings on July 29th, and it seems that their overall performance in this past quarter has been positive. Therefore, I believe that the stock price will tend upwards following this announcement. However, since earnings announcement don't usually cause more a huge swing in either direction (usually it's less than 10% swing), I think it's reasonable to expect a stock price distribution centered around the current price, with the majority of the probability mass within a 10% shift in either direction.

Baseline: Stock is currently at 233. Ceiling over past year is 245 and floor was 146 during COVID crash but has since rebounded to 220-245 range. Past news over public backlash around events like Cambridge Analytica and the Facebook Supreme Court haven't substantially hit stock.
Context-specific: But an advertiser boycott would hit bottom line more than simply media backlash and a small percentage of users dropping. in other words, there's a tail risk that current advertiser pullback could hit bottom line. Furthermore, COVID shock may have a lagged effect on advertising that reduces earnings guidance despite Fed interventions in market which widens the downside.

Using volatility, one can obtain a good baseline estimate for Facebook as many other forecasters here have noted. In the coming weeks, the largest events that could potentially swing FB's stock price from a sector's perspective are earnings releases on 7/29, as well as big tech's antitrust investigation by Congress. I'd expect earnings to be much more of a wild card, as the latter has been talked about since early this year, and results are general inconclusive, especially given how slow Congress moves on issues. The largest story here is how ad boycotting has affected Facebook during Q2, and if that's enough for investors to be worried about the long-term impact on Facebook's stock price. I'd argue that generally tech will perform at expectations, especially given how they are comparatively less affected by work from home than other industries. Therefore, since FB is at $233 right now, it's most likely to be in the middle bucket but has a larger downside potential than upside, especially given its volatility.  https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-antitrust-hearing-congress-big-tech-explained-2020-7
https://www.forbes.com/sites/jjkinahan/2020/07/27/how-well-has-fb-handled-the-pandemic-and-ad-boycott-q2-earnings-ahead/#2452a3526454

Current facebook stock price is 233. So it makes sense that the 200-230 and 230-260 buckets will get the most weight. Facebook hasn't been below 200 since the end of April, and it's  never gone above 260. However, earnings are soon and the stock has surged over the second half of the year, and with pandemic improvement, I can see it happening. The tails are clearly improbable, with the low end tail more probable. Since the current price is > 230, and trending upwards, i give it higher odds for that bucket, with a significant but not majority probability of 260+

As of 7/27/2020, the closing price was $233.50. 8/21/2020 at-the-money options indicate an implied volatility of roughly 44.50%, which loosely corresponds to a distribution of probabilities 0.0265/0.393/0.517/0.062/0.001 of the above bounds. There is one important event left (Antitrust testimony) that will occur on 7/29/2020. Given how fairly well-known this event is despite the rescheduling from Monday to Wednesday, I firmly believe that the event volatility has been priced in to the above options. Facebook almost certainly will deny monopolistic behaviors, as seen in the past by other major corporations, which is already reflected in its stock price. However, the directional risk should be move heavily weighted in the downside, as testimony can only ever hurt the stock price. As a result, I have slightly increased the percentages underneath the current stock price (and decreased the percentages over the current stock price).
Climbing on the fence until earnings announced.

Similar to other forecasters, I decided to determine my baseline probabilities by backtracking from options expiring on August 7th with the strikes of 200, 230, 260, and 290. I recognize the potential expiration issues given the earnings on Thursday; however, simultaneously we observe no likely significant events between the 5th and 7th, allowing us to utilize these values as a fair base rates.  Performing the calculations leaves me with an approximated distribution of: 4, 44, 47, 5, 0. The methods of backtracking from options prices fails to fully take into account potential macroeconomic trends or perform any strict fundamental analysis of Facebook's pricing. With the announced delay of Facebook's earning date, we have a D-Day of sorts on July 30th as FAANG as a whole release their earnings. SNAP and Twitter, for instance, provides a market outlook on overall sentiment post-earnings as they both beat their expected EPS.  The potential second wave of COVID-19 and the increased redirection of advertising spend towards alternate clients compared to FAANG likely has some implication on the FB pricing. Nonetheless, I argue that this negative sentiment has already been taken into some account based off of Twitter and SNAP's earnings. More important will be Facebook's engagement numbers and penetration within their various social media platforms. Thus, in spite of an overwhelming amount of negative news sentiment towards FB's stance towards Trump and Q2 GDP figures likely depressing the market, the overall strong recovery of FAANG alongside Facebook's strength in penetration within consumers and their platforms skew my distribution more towards the 230-260 range for a final distribution of: 3, 31, 61, 5, 0.
Hard to see it going outside of the 200 - 260 range.

https://www.jewishexponent.com/2020/07/27/thousands-join-48-hour-nosafespaceforjewhate-twitter-boycott/ https://fortune.com/2020/07/27/facebook-twitter-social-media-criticized-election-2020-trump-biden-campaigns/ twitter has announced earnings on Thu 23 July 2020, and had a very strong trading day on that Thursday. By today, the stock price is down to where is was before earnings, so in less than two trading days, and even a bit lower (being one of the large losers in S&P 500 today), probably still on news concerning the bitcoin hack, their own scandal-turned-boycott, and the difficulties "navigating the political minefield", where twitter is now under attack from POTUS for moderating his "content".

FB stock is currently $232.22. People have expected FB’s ad sales this quarter to have taken a hit because of the impact to travel and automobile industries; in addition, operating system changes from AAPL and GOOGL have limited FB’s ability to track activity. Just today, FB announced they are postponing their Q2 announcement by a day to allow Zuckerberg to appear before a Congressional hearing. I think this delay, combined with residual volatility from earnings trickling into the week of August 5th, flattens the middle part of the distribution. Even so, the overall tech sector has had positive drift over the last month; even with a massive shock in stock price from earnings, I believe the majority of the distribution still falls in the middle two buckets, with a slight edge to the downside.

To consider closing stock price of facebook on Aug 5th, I looked at options that expire on Aug 7 with strike 200, 230, 260, 290, to back out the market expectation for the option to expire in the money for each of these strikes. This seems like a fair judgment to do because there is no major event that is expected to happen between the 5th and the 7th. This provided me with a base rate of approximately, 7, 30,40,20, 3.  Other factors that may not be inherently captured by this judgement that I think I should factor are the recent earnings of other tech companies in the preceding weeks such as Twitter which performed better EPS than expected. Updated beliefs in how FB earnings are going to perform on the 29th will be that they should likewise now perform better as both were significantly affected by the advertiser boycotts. As a result, I think that they're going to negatively affect the given perception that any subsequent lack of performance will be even harsher on the stock in the following days. Also, Q2 GDP earnings are scheduled to release on the 30th which I perceive has higher risk of negatively impacting the stock than increasing. Adjusting my beliefs, I've arrived at the above weights, assigning greater probability on the two middling events of staying at the level or dropping just a tiny bit.
will have an initial drop but will be propped up. Advertiser don't boycott. Its to big and powerful and now diverse
Still think my upside is too high.

Facebook is now trading at 230 with a couple days to their earnings results.  As mentioned before, these earnings typically do not move the stock more than 10% in either direction, and should see about a 75% move. All my other logic stays the same, but due to the lower current price with less trading days, it is important to recenter my distribution. Furthermore, it is now possible given a tumultuous state of events on earning day that the stock inches 200, but also much less likely to close over 290, changing by more than 290 and less than 200 to 1% each. In addition the second bucket probability should increase, as given a bad earnings report, it is very likely will close in the 200-230 range. I will adjust the forecast again following the day after earning.

The largest drivers by far for Facebook stock are SPX and FAANG - these explain 80-90%+ of the variance, especially over such short time periods. Modelling FB as a geometric brownian motion over daily prices with a volatility of 3,4% (backed out from call/put annualized implied volatilities on options from now to August 7). This gives a log-return volatility of about 10.75% over the 10-day time period from now to August 5. Given the current stock price of Facebook sits in between two buckets, we should also have a roughly symmetrical distribution. Applying the given volatilities, a brownian motion should have about a 80% chane of staying within the $200-260 bands. I also biased my probabilities upwards as the Fed's continued buying and a new fiscal stimulus bill seem to cap downside on stocks in general, and FAANG sentiment seems to have barely slowed, even on worse than expected earnings from Netflix. The main risk here is idio-variance contribution from Facebook on an awful or amazing earnings report (July 29), creating a bimodal distribution.

I see what most other people on the team have done, and agree to the backing-out probability distributions to some degree. However, there's a quarterly earnings report for July 29; if we look at previous quarterly earnings, it seems like the day of and the day after there's over 2x traded daily volume, as well as large price shock. For example, in the April 29 earnings report where  EPS Actual$1.71
EPS SurpriseBeat by$0.01
Revenue Actual$17.74B
Revenue SurpriseBeat by$524.77M the +$0.01 earnings per share and 0.5B revenue actual over expectation caused price to go from 190 to 206 the following day and 2x volume traded 4/29 and 4/30. Furthermore, it seemed these affects carried well over into the week following earnings, and Aug 5 is included in the 7/29/2020 earnings report we're looking at now. So, with projected revenue the exact same as last quarter but $1.37 EPS instead of $1.71, and with how large these buckets for ranges are in GJO, coupled with no serious positive or negative FB news since the last quarter (in fact, slightly positive drift in overall tech sector as more people turn to technology and SaaS in times of still-quarantine), we can probably safely assume the lion's share of the probability for stock price will be in the 200-230 and 230-260 range, with much more towards the latter due to earnings expectations and overall tech sector trends and stability. More time and in-depth analysis would include looking at historical earnings reports and seeing market reactions to earnings expectations and / or earnings reality vs. expectations, as well as looking at other companies within the sector (snap, msft, etc.) and how they're reacting / earnings.

Reverse implied probabilities of spot price from normal approximation using IV of remaining trading days. Will have to keep a very close eye on the earnings report on the 29th as well as COVID and ad boycott news. Have a slight edge to upward trend due to relatively steady rise of FB since its covid dip in March

Using options that expire on Aug 7 with strike 200, 230, 260, 290, we can back out the market expectation for the option to expire in the money for each of these strikes by calculating N'(d+). Since currently there is no major event that is specifically expected to happen on exactly Aug 6 or Aug 7, Aug 7 options is a good proxy for market expectation of Aug 5 price. We can use the market expectation as a base rate for the forecast. Since option pricing is mostly based on mathematical models and involves no fundamentally analysis, it did not take into account the recent irrationality and behavioral bias of the market, which makes the stock price unexplainably high. Given that this irrationality of stock market is not likely to end before Aug 5, I further adjusted the price upward from the base probability implied by option prices.
Revising downward due to current stock price as time to setttlement approaches.

Since the FB earnings will be released next week. For now, based on its performance over the last several months, I  tend to believe that its earnings will turn out good and so its price will go up.
The pattern should be clearer after the earnings.
$230 now. Earnings estimates are in the positive so share price should stay here or higher. With more staying at home the usage should remain high.

The stock price ended up at 230.71 on Jul. 26th. I would update my prediction based on similar reasoning as well as  new stock price. In addition, I would take into account that there's higher than 0 percent possibility that Facebook stock price will be lower than 200 on Aug 5th.

Bracket borders in percent of current price (230,71): 86|99.7|112|125 
Base rates over eight business days since May 2012: 2|53|42|3|0
Crowd: 0|25|72|3|0 Corrected forecast: 1|52|44|3|0

The current FB price is 230.71 at July 24th close, which serves as a baseline. 1. FB earnings is expected to be on July 29th, which could cause a big move that day. Given the recent rally, the earnings has limited room for upside and more room for the downside. 2. The overall market is a recovery story with support from central banks and fiscal policy. I hadn't realized we had access to Bloomberg weekly options data until recently, so instead of hypothetical Aug5 options, I'll use the Aug7 option prices. The price is much closer to $230 than it was one week ago, so my probability of less than 230 has increased notably. Aug7 $200 put: $1.05
Aug7 $200 call: $31.50
Aug7 $230 put: $9.11
Aug7 $260 call: $1.30
Aug7 $290 call: $0.15
Aug7 $260 put: $31.50
Aug7 $230 call: $9.75 Calculating values for each range the same way as the last forecast gives:
Less than 200: $1.05
Between 200, 230: $14.91
Between 230, 260: $15.42
Between 260, 290: $1.15
Above 290: $0.15 Scaling these into percents gives:

I used the the at the money straddle that expired August 7th to find out what the option implied price distribution was. I estimated that straddle should have an EV of zero, so I  centered the distribution around the current price and backed out the z-score of the price distribution knowing the approximate middle 50% of values. I then calculated probabilities and set these as my base rate. I thinned out the tail ends and weighted towards the downside due to my belief of lower earnings from less ad spending due to coronavirus and FB refusing to take down certain political ads.

I have been mistakenly forecasting a similar question.
https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1690-will-the-closing-price-of-facebook-stock-be-higher-on-5-august-2020-than-it-was-on-7-july-2020 Here is my adaption forecast for this question. There are a few important events to highlight that will strongly influence Facebook stock. On 7/29, after market close, FB will release earnings. EPS expectations are lower that any of the past four quarters, due to new headwinds facing adverting revenues. The company has been subject to an advertiser boycott for not policing the veracity of content on the platform more closely, and lack of removing hate speech. Earnings will likely have a large impact on whether or not the stock price is up or down on the time interval considered.  Currently, we are in the midst of earnings season. Twitter reports earnings on 7/23. Snap reports on 7/21. Apple and Amazon report on 7/30. These are all events that could affect the stock price of FB, positively or negative depending on if industry trends are elucidated.  Finally, the federal reserve will report Q2 GDP figures on 7/30. This is likely to have a large impact on all equities. The median forecast is currently -31% (according to marketwatch) compared to the same quarter last year. This will potentially depress stocks further as retail investors respond to this news. FB stock closed at $240.86 on July 7. Today, FB closed at $245.42. There are 12 remaining trading days before August 5th. From implied volatility in options prices, we can calculate and model the distribution of predicted FB prices by the market. The August 7th 245 straddle is trading at $23.10, (this accounts for 14 trading days, not 12). A fine estimate is that the straddle at the current stock price for expiry on 8/5 would be trading at about $20. (In 50% of cases, the stock price would remain within $20 from the stock price). We can approximate the distribution of FB stock by using options expiring on 8/7. From these options, implied volatility in FB stock from now until Aug 7th is 54.73% annually. There are 12 trading days inclusive of the 5th of August. Implied volatility over the next 12 trading days can be calculated as Vol = 54.7% / sqrt(252/12) = 12% So we can expect that the distribution of FB prices is going to be normal with a mean of $245.42 and a std of 12% or $30. With this insight, a prediction can be made. <200 : 6%
200-230: 24%
230-260: 39%
260-290: 25%
290< : 6%

We can first look at the extreme cases. Facebook is currently trading at 245.42 with 12 trading days left. The world has pretty much accepted Coronavirus, and thus we do not expect any drastic falls  so we can rule 200 with probability 0. Now, we must concern the two key events that could affect the Facebook price; the earnings on July 29 and the ongoing agenda of banning political/un-fact checked ads.  The earnings typically does not move the price more than 10%, but we must account for a potential 10% move in either direction. Furthermore, the facebook ad ban and hearings have not had a huge impact on the price, as I have spoke to several domain experts and looked at the price. We can now look at the chance of a price over $290, this can happen if they beat earnings and go up (18/31) times, and trend upward after and before. To quantify this, I would put the chance at about 5%. We also know that most likely the price will be around the current price, so we can set that to the highest probability. Furthermore, the upside is more likely than the downside, arriving at my forecast.
Assuming Q2 does not disapoint, steady as she goes.

FB has a huge footprint and good bones. By that token, bargain hunters will keep the price buoyed against further discounts in the short-term. I don't imagine a major swing upward anytime soon, and a huge dip will certainly be preceded by some obviously egregious misstep.

My forecast is based on options price data.  I saw how others used option prices in their forecasts and wanted to suggest an improvement on that method.  The price of a call spread divided by the difference in strikes is roughly equal to the probability that the call spread expires in the money.  (Think about the limiting case as the difference in strikes goes to 0 to see why—in this limit it is exactly true).  This can be used to back out a market-implied CDF for the stock price at expiration.  I used option prices in the Aug 7 weekly expiration to find these values using the closest available strikes.  I used the call spreads with boundaries at the relevant stock prices, and took the average of the two implied probabilities to back out what the implied probability would be very roughly for a call spread centered on the relevant value.   I think that this distribution is a fairly good "base rate" for the distribution on Aug 5.  However, there are a couple of things to consider.  First and most obvious is that there are two days between the end of this question and the expiration of the weekly options.  As compared with other approaches others have taken using monthly options however, we don't have to make any assumptions about earnings or interpolate across an earnings event.  If there are any events expected on the 6th or 7th, however, it could be important to take these into account and potentially adjust option prices accordingly.  If anyone knows of any, let me know and we can try to make this adjustment. As far as any other adjustments to these values go, I am fairly confident that the market collectively knows much more about factors affecting Facebook's stock price in the coming weeks than I do, so I don't think there is anything for me to gain by adjusting this base rate to include my own view. This forecast should be updated if any events are expected for Facebook, or anything materially affects their business.  I also plan to periodically update this base rate forecast to reflect changing prices.  This forecast is current as of 10CT Jul 20.
Assuming we will be on the bubble at close time.

To somewhat account for this, my estimated synthetic "August 5th" option prices will now more heavily weight August 21 options because they each share the earnings component (a rough estimate is 2/3 weight on the August option). There are approximately four weeks until August 5, 2020. As a base rate, the average monthly return for Facebook in the last five years has been about 1.5%, giving an initial estimate of $250. This includes periods of investigation and pressure from US and European regulatory bodies. While Facebook has been facing an advertiser boycott over hate speech monitoring on the site, the company has also faced criticism in the past and its share price has continued to increase. This will hold true depending on whether public interest in and awareness of the boycott continues to hold in the coming weeks. A more important determinant will be Facebook's quarterly earnings release one week before the forecast date. Earnings results, especially surprises relative to analyst estimates, have largely driven price moves in the week following past announcements.  However, Facebook's beta (correlation) to the wider market performance is 1.2 (5 year monthly), and has in fact increased recently, as market stress has led to more correlation between stocks. So, while earnings may have driven returns in the past, macro factors such as the expected uptick in new cases over the next few weeks may be more/just as important. This has led me to shift my estimate downwards. I have also increased the weighting on each tail to reflect the possibilities of a nation-wide second wave of cases or news of a treatment/vaccine.

On Jul. 10th, Facebook closed at 245.07, higher than Jul.7th and a step away from its historical high. Though the bad news of advertiser boycott made FB stock drop sharply initially, it quickly regained its territory and broke its previous high. Therefore, I won’t be worrying too much on the negative impact brought by advertiser boycott as market has already priced in that component. Assume stock follows a Geometric Brownian Motion, since right now the stock price is a bit higher than the reference price, and interest rate right now is pretty close to 0, I will assign a base mean around $245 and follows a log normal distribution. The major driver for Facebook stock is COVID-19. As daily new cases continuously achieve daily record, and with fed providing enough liquidity to prevent systematic failure, tech companies like Facebook/Google/Amazon benefit greatly. Right now, I believe it is similar to April/May 2020, where value of technology companies was gradually discovered by the market.  Factors that can bring down the price may include bad earning news for the company, scandals, systematic liquidity issues, etc. However, most of these risks have been handled (e.g. systematic liquidity by FED) or absorbed by the market. Therefore, I would adjust my prior more towards the up side and give a log normal distribution with mean around $260 (a right skewed distribution).

At the time of posting, there are approximately four weeks until the forecast settles. While not incredibly informative, I begin by heuristically examining the average change in Facebook’s stock price over four week periods during the past two years. We usually see 2-3% price increases. I do not think the advertiser boycott is going to remain a significant issue in the coming weeks as (a) brands are responding to increased public awareness which fades quickly and (b) Facebook’s stock price has gained over the past years despite similar pressure from regulatory bodies (for tax and anti-competitive practices). In my mind, the earnings report presents a much more difficult problem. Broadly speaking, stock prices react to earnings relative to expectation as opposed to in absolute terms. Hence, it is usually not sufficient to argue about stock price moves based on the public analyst expectation alone. In addition, looking at the four most recent earnings releases, Facebook’s stock price has only returned to pre-earnings levels within the subsequent week once. (The forecast similarly closes one week after earnings.) This indicates that the result of the forecast could be influenced significantly by the earnings results. All things considered, my forecast remains primarily in line with the historical changes in Facebook’s stock price. However, I would allocate more probability to Facebook’s stock decreasing. This is solely due to the potential of an earnings miss. If I had to guess, I would argue that Facebook may not have benefited as much as expected from the coronavirus pandemic. I attribute this to other technology companies which have done a better job of engaging users (notably Zoom vs Facebook rooms) during the lockdown period.

The current price of FB (July 10) is $242.72. As of now, there is no indication of a dividend by August 5. Given the way the question's answer is asked above, I thought it might be a good idea to look at option prices with the strikes corresponding to the bounds above. For example, I could look at a $230 strike put option to estimate the probability that FB price goes below $230. The current price of a July 17 230 put is around $1.47, and the price of an Aug 21 230 put is around $9.45. I don't know the ins and outs of Black Scholes yet, so I can't get an exact volatility measure of some sort (that could be a helpful calculation if someone is skilled in Black Scholes). However, given the lack of a dividend, it's fair to say that a hypothetical Aug 5 230 put would be priced between $1.47 and $9.45. For now, I'll just do a weighted average (by # of business days) of the two dates' options to get 13/25*$1.47 + 12/25*$9.45=$5.300. Likewise, I can get a value of a hypothetical Aug 5 260 option as 13/25*$0.70+12/25*$7.50=$3.964. Doing the same for $200, $290 gives a summary below: Hypothetical Aug5 $200 put: $1.325
Hypothetical Aug5 $230 put: $5.300
Hypothetical Aug5 $260 call: $3.964
Hypothetical Aug5 $290 call: $0.805 We get that the value of $230put-$200put is $3.975 and the value of $260call-$290call is $3.159. As a very rough approximation, we can guess that these prices are rough proportions of percent within each range (when I have more time to think about this later, I imagine I'll change this logic). For these ratios to be usable, I must also estimate the probability that the price lies within the $230-$260 range. I can estimate this by taking two more Hypothetical Aug5 calls and puts: Hypothetical Aug5 $260 put: $21.840
Hypothetical Aug5 $230 call: $17.608 Using these values to estimate our $230-$260 range gives $21.840-5.300=$16.54 or $17.608-$3.964=$13.644. Ideally these would give the same value, but so many assumptions and estimates went in, we can give our "price" to the $230-$260 range as the average: $15.092. Then our prices for each range are:
Less than 200: $1.325
Between 200, 230: $3.975
Between 230, 260: $15.092
Between 260, 290: $3.159
Above 290: $0.805 Scaling these into percents gives:
Less than 200: 5%
Between 200, 230: 17%
Between 230, 260: 62%
Between 260, 290: 13%
Above 290: 3% This is just a crude initial estimate, and will need to be updated to be both more precise and to update given future options prices.
July 9=242.43 mid-day down 1/2%. A nervous market and a company under pressure could test the recent lows of 216 or 205. Pessimistic short term, but I've been wrong before.

prior: I assume it is possible to use options pricing to determine exact market expectations are and use this figure for my prior. However, I am not sure how to do it, so I will take a less robust approach to prior calculation. Currently, the stock is at 243 and average vol hovers around 0.32 for the next month. Therefore, I will assume a 2% daily move from now until August. Although I couldn't find FB's Q2 earnings date, last year it's been in late July (July 24th) therefore I expect this year's earnings to be around roughly the same time. I expect this to be a large catalyst given uncertainty around advertiser boycotts, increasing government regulation/scrutiny of the platform, retailer/advertiser bankruptcy (Brooks Brothers, J Crew, etc), and general COVID anxiety. Given this catalyst and the high vol, I expect FB to have a relatively flat normal distribution of returns around the 230-260 bucket. Therefore my prior is a 10, 20, 40, 20, 10 distribution.  Likelihood: now to adjust for the above. Firstly, I believe equity markets, although a little rattled, will rally on any good COVID-related news. Given 100+ drugs in the vaccine pipeline and most countries being able to control their pandemics, I believe the tide of news will tilt positive. I believe the virus will force Republican governors to enact (relatively) strict lockdowns, which should contain virus spread. However, the timing of this is unclear, with my COVID projection conservatively assuming 1 month until they do, which would imply that the conditions would only worsen in the US until then. Even if this happens, I believe many pure software companies like FB are largely immune from any negative news related to rising deaths/infections - in Q1 the company reported only modest declines in ad revenue (down 17% YoY in Q1) and saw conditions stabilize. Therefore, I believe ad declines for the company are at or near bottom. All of the above makes me tilt positive to 5, 15, 40, 25, 15.  On the other hand, advertiser boycotts and increased government regulation remain the main risks for the company in our analysis (ie until August). Government regulation is likely to be focused on Chinese tech and not American tech for the time being, especially with the pandemic and US Tech firms' actions in HK. The ad boycott is an interesting issue to analyze. On one hand, the cynical side of me says that, companies will continue to advertise as long as they can make money via FB (clearly demonstrable given ad analytics). This side of me says that FB will do some surface level/moderate reforms which will be enough for these companies to save face when returning to the FB platform. This side of me says that companies are pulling back because of cash conservation (due to COVID - think Levis and sales down 70% YoY and they pulled out) and virtue signaling (socially acceptable/trendy/way to boost sales). This side of me also says that FB's $70bn in revenue in FY2019 is difficult to hit hard, especially when FB's largest advertiser, HD, only spends 178m (in FY2019). So even if all top 10 advertisers pulled out and had HD's ad spend (not true since MSFT in #3 only spent 115m. Regardless, even if all 10 pulled out completely, then FB loses 1.8bn in revenue off a 70bn base (has to be adjusted for COVID of course). On the other hand, it is possible that this time is different (in that a boycott actually forced a large corporation to fundamentally change) - massive social unrest & record unemployment aren't helping. However, I would not adjust my distribution of percentages given that I think Mark & the FB team are smart enough to handle this type of issue (however big it actually is). Therefore, my final distribution is 5, 15, 40, 25, 15.
I see a price target in the range of 210 to 222USD, most likely 220USD on 05 August 2020.
